header.description: Full-stack engineer. I work across Web3 (DeFi, Solidity, wagmi/viem) and Web2 (CRM, Firebase, Express). I care about type safety, tests, CI/CD, and clean UX. Recently supported an EVM-based DeFi protocol frontend from zero to $40M+ TVL.
header.title: About

metadata.description: Full-stack engineer specializing in Next.js, TypeScript, and Web3/DeFi. Focused on type safety, testing, and CI/CD.
metadata.title: About — Satoshi Ogura

items.tokyo: The University of Tokyo, Graduate School of Frontier Sciences

napier.description: Built V2 web frontend for an EVM DeFi protocol, largely solo. Tech: TypeScript, Next.js, Tailwind, wagmi, viem, GraphQL, Zod, Neverthrow, Vercel, Sentry.

header.description: Explore helpers for cancellable timers and infrastructure-friendly error handling. The example below shows how <sleep>sleep</sleep> produces an Infra-layer error when aborted.
header.title: Asynchronous utilities

metadata.description: Demonstration of the cancellable sleep helper from @o3osatoshi/toolkit.
metadata.title: Toolkit · Asynchronous utilities

card.description: Simulate a cancellable pause that rejects with an infrastructure error when aborted.
card.title: Sleep helper demo

demo.description: Start the demo to run a three-second delay. Abort the operation to see the helper reject with an <infraError>InfraCanceledError</infraError> that preserves the abort reason.
demo.title: Cancellable sleep

metadata.title: Toolkit

items.redisCache: Redis cache: speeding up a slow API with Upstash

header.description: This demo calls a deliberately slow API endpoint exposed by the interface service at <endpoint>/edge/public/heavy</endpoint> and uses the Upstash cache adapter from <integrations>@repo/integrations</integrations> to cache the response. Requests within the TTL are served from cache; once the TTL expires, the next request recomputes the value by hitting the slow API again.
header.title: Redis cache

metadata.description: Demonstration of using the Upstash cache adapter from @repo/integrations to cache a slow API response.
metadata.title: Toolkit · Redis cache

card.description: Call a deliberately slow API endpoint (<endpoint>/edge/public/heavy</endpoint>) via the interface service and cache the result in Redis. Subsequent requests within the TTL should be served from cache and return much faster.
card.title: Redis cache demo

demo.description: Press the button below multiple times. The first request should take roughly three seconds as it hits the slow API. Subsequent requests within the cache TTL will be significantly faster and marked as "Redis cache"; after the TTL expires, the next request will become slow again and refresh the cached value.
demo.title: Cached slow endpoint
